comments.commentBody: I'm with you all the way. I'm AARP age now, but in my 20s and 30s when people did something cruel they were immediately and permanently out of my life. There was one night a group of us were walking away from a Manhattan party and this nasty man married to an acquaintance tripped me and I fell on my face and was fairly seriously injured. He just laughed and laughed. He just stood there and I ran away from the group and got a cab. Hilarious, right? Why do people get their jollies this way?

my father used to hold me or my mother down and tickle us until we wet our clothing. we hated it, screamed, and asked him to stop. "oh, but it's FUN," he would say, "see, you're laughing!" it wasn't fun, and we were hysterical, not laughing. it was, simply, abuse. he tried to continue it with me into my teens until the time I kicked him in the face. it did absolutely nothing for my own self-esteem, knowing that any man that could overpower me, might just do that.

Possibly. Part of my approach was from having an older sister (2 years) who would torture me (I was a shrimp), and then when I finally whacked her, turn to our mother and tearfully claim, "He hit a girl!". Kids do things like that.
I am not deliberately blaming the victim, but I think both parents can gently change this behavior without drawing special attention (guilt or fear) to it. I don't think she is a seductive child and I don't think he is a molester; it's just time that this game quietly went away with no special guilt or explanation. People outgrow things over time. This is the time for that.

Developmental psychologist?!?!
"He may think of it as strengthening his relationship with your daughter and perhaps as building her resilience too"

What the ?!?!? Dad is making her daughter cry, this means, he is hurting your daughter and enjoying it. Nothing matters after this, tickle torture has to stop. Don't need a therapist to tell you this.

Mom, please don't just stand there, shield daughter from pain and abuse that she is too young to understand, but old enough to cry because it hurts.

Ethicist, I can't believe you and your long winded attempt at finding good in dad's behavior. Simplified:

Dad daughter tears = full stop always.

Should have written to Judge H instead, would have gotten a more humane and on point response.

First, if Pence had to pray before doing the right thing on the HIV crisis, he evidently hasn't prayed enough to temper the rest of the GOP's agenda with the slightest bit of human decency. He could start by praying to prevent the proposed immigrant detention program that would brutally separate children form their parents. I imagine the effect on my young granddaughters of such a thing.

Secondly, why is it that that people who live in the interior expect us on the coasts (btw, I live in a coastal state but 400 miles inland) to be considerate of their feelings without themselves offering the same consideration in return. It seems like a one-way street.

That said, I'm all for a compulsory national service program that sends young people to serve the deprived areas of our country, rural and urban, coastal and interior. If that comes about, maybe young Barron Trump will be able to teach his dad a thing or two.

What is described in the letter is child abuse, period. The father doesn't have a right to decide abuse is okay. It is not. Also, the parents need to find a way (with or without help) to agree on parenting rules. But first, dad needs to stop being a bully.

The answer to letter #2 is just wrong.  No means no, regardless of the gender, age, or relationship of the individuals involved.  When my son was younger, his aunt loved to tickle him, but he hated it and would beg her to stop while laughing hopelessly (he is extremely ticklish).  I would intervene, but she didn't get it, and eventually it would happen again.  When he was 9 or 10 years old, he told me that he didn't want to see his aunt anymore because he really hated the fact that she always tickled him even though he told her not to.  I spoke with her separately, she stopped, and now several years later they have a good relationship.  Bottom line, a child has the same right as an adult to set limits regarding physical boundaries and to decide when an activity stops being fun.  The father needs to understand that if his child is saying "no" the appropriate reaction is to pause and ask her if she would prefer to stop, or if she really wants to continue, and then proceed based solely on her verbalized preference, not his.  And by the way, "Oh, but you started it!" is what I would expect to hear from the child, not the dad.
I'm sorry, I'm stuck on the fact that two adults allowed children to be driven around by someone who was likely high. what the heck?

Why is The Ethicist giving a long answer to the second letter?  The father should stop.  Period!  I'm also concerned about the mother asking if she's "doing more harm than good by making dad uncomfortable."  Is she afraid of this man?  There may unfortunately be more to this situation.

I found the ethicist's reply shockingly uninformed. Dad sounds like an immature overgrown bully at the least and a pedophile at the worst. I agree, it has to stop, for all the reasons cited by other readers.
"Stop" means stop.  Period.
I unfortunately am familiar with this game.  The child is being abused and so is the mother in that she is being prevented from protecting the child.

I am absolutely horrified that the ethicist would say anything other than "No means NO". EVERY human being, ANY age, has the right to BODILY AUTONOMY. Your body is your own and no one else's.

The Children's Rights International Network defines it as this:
The principle of bodily integrity sums up the right of each human being, including children, to autonomy and self-determination over their own body. It considers an unconsented physical intrusion as a human rights violation.

NOBODY has the right to touch you if you don't want touched. No one has the right to tickle you, hug you, touch you in ANY way if you don't want it. Toddlers don't have to kiss grandma if they don't want to. Girls don't have to give in to coercion. ANY parent thinking they can override their child's right to control of their own body is doing irreparable harm.

My dad would do this to me. In all eyes it was "just fun" I would have to cry and get mad before it would end. I was then called a baby or sissy and told to grow up. I have and now have almost no relationship with him today and still don't like being hugged at 50. No means no and stop means stop.
This is harmful to the child, boy or girl.
I, too, climbed Katahdin.  I did use the Knife Edge trail.  That's where I found out I have acrophobia.  Not a pleasant experience.  However, I did get a gimme so it wasn't a complete loss.

Well done Emily. Please let us not normalise Trump, Sessions, and Bannon.
The idea of a Christian, white America would horrify our founding fathers. Even Jefferson and Madison, slave holding Virginians, had more enlightened views then the current administration.
The founding fathers were a product of the 18th century enlightenment, somehow the current administration is a product of the fear and loathing of the dark ages.

Great article--thanks for the info and insights!

The extreme right wing is attempting a coup to undermine, displace, and destroy our democracy. A few years ago, I'd never have thought that something vaguely akin to this would be possible, outside a sensationalist movie. Truly scary...
America, we hardly knew ye.

poslug - Protesters may well be targeted in some fashion by the Trump administration for whatever reason, but the Obama administration did the same against Occupy Wall Street protesters.  In this way, and ongoing, are our freedoms thus restricted.  Remember how the police have been militarized over time with "leftover" war toys.

Where are we? At strategy meetings, Town Halls, protests, and offices of our representatives. Calling and writing our legislators. Recruiting the next generation of office-holders and leaders. Organizing ourselves locally, without waiting for a few top members to tell us what to do.

This election woke a sleeping giant -- a many-headed one -- and it is shaking off the lethargy of its long nap and stretching forgotten muscles, remembering how to use them. Soon, you won't be able to pretend that we aren't here or that you don't see us.

Trump/Bannon/Sessions/Miller white nationalist agenda is  more than just lax enforcement of minoriy, voting, civil rights, etc. Their hidden agenda is actual white nationalist autocracy and worse by an easily contrived use of presidential emergency powers suspending democractic rule of law and institutions, criminalization and elimination of all opposition, revolution, government and military supported civil war, racial and ethnic cleansing (guess which side has all the guns) to establish true white 'christian' national culture and demographics.

So true. It's hard to tell who's crazier - Trump, or the sane people willfully ignoring his core message of utter depravity and sadism.

How is ending Medicaid for children, the disabled, the indigent, and low-paid gig economy workers something to cheer about? Will filthy tar sands oil oozing through patriotic American steel purify our drinking water? And how about that school choice bonanza? Trump wants to dumb down citizens into a formless blob while enriching his fellow rent-seeking vultures beyond their sickest dreams.

Scariest of all is the new Homeland Security agency called VOICE: Victims of Immigration Crime Engagement. This bureaucratic pitting of white people ("victims") against brown and black people ("criminals") has been termed pre-genocidal, and for very good reason.

Just witness the spate of freelance attacks and threats against Jews, Muslims, Latinos, any "Other" at all. Trump is making America feel safe, all right - safe enough to smash moral compasses and shred human decency.

He can turn his persona on and off like a switch. So for anybody who still thinks that this psychopath should be praised for acting so damned "presidential," please think again.

Do what I did. Listen to his speech with Wagner's "Ride of the Valkyries" playing the background. It truly enhances the experience, brings the fascistic essence right up to the surface.

Then again, so does the reinvention of war criminal Bush as the comical cowboy of kitsch.

.

Karen Garcia...I 'm sure you won't see this innocuous note from N innocuous old, average man....but I pleased to say to the Cloud that I'm
Pleased to see your se of "Psychopath" in connection of our faker-in-chief.
As a long-retired licensed psychotherapist, I have long agreed. His real
personality will revert...as already evident.

But there's no point in talking to the "sane people" who support him for their own gain; they have no morality to appeal to.  And no point in talking to people who support him because they like his messages of division and hate.  Witness PI Sonny, responding to this comment, who does not know what a "hate crime" is, and uses the occasion to speak of bad "colored people".  No point in talking to him.  We need to get out the vote, and to get political power over the people who will not change, but will wreck the nation if they are not overcome.

Most of the sickest, most heinous crimes reported in this nation have been committed by good old white men and women. Therefore it seems odd that you want to note and call out black crime but apparently overlook or deliberately ignore white caused crime. Crime is crime, murder is murder. Crime is not owned by a skin color, if it were it would be called "White Crime".

We were given lists of people to call, leads, and we were instructed to hard sell them on cash out mortgages. Got the leads straight from the banks. We had new rate sheets on our desks every morning with rates on BCD loans. Our job was strictly re-fi. Other outfits did other things, we did that. We turned people with old 10-15 and 20 year old mortgages into new customers with a pocket full of cash. First thing they did usually was buy a new Lexus. It's where I sent them right after I closed the deal...had a pal working at the dealer. I got a nice bird dog on that too. People sure do love to spend money. It's not on me how they blew that load of cash, but they did. Always. Unfortunately, that new higher payment didn't agree with them either.  We closed deals in visiting rooms in jails. With terminally ill patients in hospitals. Old trusting widows. People who hadn't had a job in years and had a paid off home. Or a house literally rotting away. Sign here....and here. And here. And here. Now here. Ect..it's the American way. Look who ya'll elected President. It's what America loves. And does. You can't fix stupid.

I  became an activist for rolling back the drug war when I was 66, and finally, 18 years later, am seeing some progress. My only hope now is that Congress, and the Supreme Court, will rein in these "men of zeal, but without understanding", as Justice Brandeis wrote in 1929 about prohibitionists.

Lets settle the sugar argument by just insisting that cereals be un-sweetened. If we need it we can add it ourselves. As an old timer we had sugared cereals on the shelves. To this day I do not like the amounts that are added. So I dilute the cereal with uncooked oats and un-sugared Greek yogurt topped off with in season chopped fruit. I leave the bacon and eggs for lunch.
